body.p: In general, you should find packages that were specifically made for your distribution. Do not compile from source yourself unless you are certain you have to or want to. Do not compile from Git unless you really need some specific feature that is not released yet, or want to help out developing GStreamer.

DL.DD:
Most, if not all, Linux distributions provide packages of GStreamer. You should find these in your distribution's package repository.
Note that some distributions split the GStreamer plugins up further than the upstream sources. Additionally, some distributions do not include the gst-plugins-bad, gst-plugins-ugly, and gst-ffmpeg packages in their main repository, for legal reasons.
Packages for various architectures are available, see the OpenBSD ports page.

The GStreamer project itself to not provide Windows binaries at this point unfortunately. However there are a couple of good options provided by the wider community.
The GStreamer winbuilds project for instance has provided up-to-date binaries of GStreamer and plugin packages for some time now.
Developers wishing to build GStreamer on Windows using MSVC may want to look at OABuild which provides a fast and convenient way to build GStreamer, GTK+, D-Bus, Telepathy (and .NET bindings for all of them) on Windows, without requiring mingw/cygwin.

The sources of the initial port of GStreamer are available for download.
Releated binary packages are also available.
Check our modules page, or go straight to our source download directory.
